titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Michele Zackheim Papers MSS.108
titlestmt.author: Yookyung Kwon (March-July 2003), Leif Sorensen (July-September 2004), Melanie Meyers-Cushman (December 2004)

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from Zackheim Finding Aid.doc

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-06-27 18:24:44 -0400.

change.item: Updated by Samantha Rowe to include materials integrated from accession 2018.084 and Jacqueline Rider, accessions 2005.108, 2008.108, and 2014.108.

did.abstract: Writer and visual artist Michele Zackheim is the author of two novels: Violette's Embrace and Einstein's Daughter: the Search for Lieserl. The Michele Zackheim Papers comprise research materials for the novels, including correspondence, manuscripts, legal documents, publicity material, photographs, books such as biographies and tourist guides, and audio and video cassettes.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
did.langmaterial: Materials primarily in English, with some in Bosnian and German.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Michele Zackheim Papers were donated to the Fales Library on December 18, 2000 by Michele Zackheim. An accretion was donated by Michele Zackheim in May of 2018; the accession number associated with the accretion is 2018.084.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection, created by Michelle Zackheim was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Writer and visual artist, Michele Zackheim is the author of two novels. Violette's Embrace: A Novel (Riverhead Books, 1996), is a fictional biography of the French writer Violette Leduc. Her second novel, Einstein's Daughter: The Search for Lieserl (Penguin Putnam, 1999), follows the mystery of the lost illegitimate daughter of Mileva and Albert Einstein. Zackheim has also worked in the visual arts as a fresco muralist, an installation artist, and a painter. She has received two NEA awards, and has taught at the School of Visual Arts in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Michele Zackheim Papers are comprised of research material, correspondence, manuscripts, legal documents, publicity material, photographs, audio and video cassettes. The research materials include a copy of August Forel's "Die Frage Sexuelle" with manuscript annotations by Mileva Maric, which was unearthed during one of Zackheim's visits to Serbia. Also included are research materials from various archival collections and duplicates of many of the legal documents related to Evelyn Einstein's lawsuit against the Einstein Family Correspondence Trust. The collection also contains source materials such as books including biographies, auction catalogs, and tours guides that focus on the life of Albert Einstein that were used to help write Zackheim's second novel, Einstein's Daughter: The Search for Lieserl, a biography of Einstein's illegitimate daughter.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records are arranged in five series that have been further arranged in five subseries. The contents of each series or subseries are arranged alphabetically or chronologically. The series and subseries arrangement of the records is as follows:
Subseries I: Miscellaneous SERIES IV: Albert Einstein Family Correspondence Trust
SERIES V: Miscellaneous writing assignments and projects

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Michele Zackheim Papers; MSS 108; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processing decisions for this collection prior to 2018 have not yet been recorded. In 2018, an accretion was rehoused in new acid-free folders and document boxes. Original caption information, when available, was transcribed onto acid-free archival folders. Materials that were loose was foldered and titled.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact fales.library@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Born-digital materials have not been transferred and may not be available to researchers. Researchers may request access copies. To request that material be transferred, or if you are unsure if material has been transferred, please contact fales.library@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content note
scopecontent.p: Contains materials related to the production of Zackheim's first novel, Violette's Embrace, a fictional biography of Violette Leduc. Organized in five subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Zackheim's research files for for Violette's Embrace, arranged alphabetically by author, where applicable, or subject. Includes correspondence and notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence between Zackheim and a range of correspondents. Arranged alphabetically by correspondent's name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes publicity materials for readings, mailings and other promotions. Arranged alphabetically by material.

container.label: Mixed Materials [31142054900926]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous materials from files for Violette's Embrace.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Comprised of research, manuscripts and correspondence related to two proposed articles on the Einstein family for The New Yorker (neither of which was published): one on Lieserl Einstein, the subject of Einstein's Daughter, and one on the legal battles of Evelyn Einstein, with whom Zackheim struck up a friendship during her research on the family. Arranged in four subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Research materials specifically related to the New Yorker assignments. Arranged alphabetically by author, where applicable, or by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Drafts and proposals for New Yorker assignments on Lieserl ("Einstein's Daughter") and Evelyn Einstein. Arranged by title and then by loose chronology.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence with Zackheim's agent, staff and editors of the New Yorker. For the bulk of Zackheim's correspondence related to Einstein see series III subseries D.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Other materials related to the New Yorker assignments that consist of expense accounting and invoices.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains materials related to the production of Zackheim's second novel, Einstein's Daughter: The Search for Lieserl, a biography of Einstein's illegitimate daughter, conceived out of wedlock when Einstein and Mileva Maric were students at Zurich Polytechnic Institute. These files were collected over the five year period in which Zackheim investigated the possible fates of Lieserl. Organized into nine subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains Michele Zackheim's research files that include notes, correspondence, books such as biographies and tourist guides, and photographs for Einstein's Daughter. The subseries is arranged alphabetically by author when relevant and subject with the exception of Michele Zackheim's note card file and research binders, which can be found at the end of the subseries. Research Binder # 4 consisting of negatives, contact sheets, and photographs was removed and transferred to subseries G, box 11.

scopecontent.p: Contains copyright information, permissions to quote and release forms, arranged alphabetically by type of document.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence to and from a broad range of sources, contacts and informants. Arranged alphabetically by correspondent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Publicity materials to promote Einstein's Daughter. Arranged alphabetically by material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes a combination of audiovisual and born digital material of recorded interviews, one videotape and two zip discs containing research material. Stored in box 9.

did.unittitle: Audio micro-cassettes documenting interviews with sources.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains original photographs of the Einstein family, duplicates of originals, photocopies and pictures documenting Zackheim's research trips, also contains negatives for some of the photographs. Originals and negatives were removed to box 10. The contents of research binder #4 were transferred to box 11. Where applicable, Zackheim's original notes and annotations have been kept with the original documents.
